description: [角](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%A7%92) is *corner*, *angle*, or *horn*, and in this context indicates a horn-shaped dumpling.

A classic dim sum item, [taro dumplings](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taro_dumpling), sometimes called *taro croquettes*, *taro puffs*, or *yam puffs* (the Chinese word for taro is also the word for sweet potato), are football-shaped shells of mashed taro enclosing a seasoned ground pork filling, deep-fried until fluffy and crispy with a honeycomb appearance. Often cut in half when served.

**Characters**

[芋](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%8A%8B) is *taro* (short for [芋頭](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%8A%8B%E9%A0%AD)), and [角](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%A7%92) is *corner*, *angle*, or *horn*, and in this context indicates a horn-shaped dumpling. So [芋角](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%8A%8B%E8%A7%92)is *taro dumpling*.

[芋](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/芋) is a shorter version of [芋頭](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%8A%8B%E9%A0%AD) wuh táu, thus this dish is also referred to as 芋頭角 wuh táu gok.

images.place: KJ Dim Sum and Seafood, Las Vegas, Nevada

description:
Deep-fried dumplings with a sticky rice-flour shell and filled with pork.

At a dim sum shop in a Vietnamese supermarket, I heard a customer refer to these dumplings as “footballs” (and the server understood), although they are not the only football-shaped dim sum.

**Characters**

[鹹](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%B9%B9) is *salty*, [水](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%B0%B4) is *water*, and [角](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%A7%92) is *horn-shaped*, so 鹹水角 is *salt water horn-shaped dumpling*.

A flaky puff pastry filled with curry and beef or potatoes.

**Characters**

[咖哩](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%92%96%E5%96%B1) is the [loanword](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loanword) for [curry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curry), and [角](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%A7%92) is *horn-shaped*.

A flaky puff pastry filled with BBQ chicken.

**Characters**

[角](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%A7%92) is *horn-shaped*,

images.place: China a Go Go, Las Vegas, Nevada

description:
A deep-fried wonton filled with cream cheese and (often imitation) crab meat. This is an American invention (the cream cheese is a tip-off), popular in Chinese-American restaurants, possibly originating at Trader Vic's.

**Characters**

[蟹](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%9F%B9) is *crab*, and [角](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%A7%92) is *horn-shaped*, so 蟹角 is *crab horn-shaped dumpling*.
